passages.text: We reflect on key themes & takeaways post H1 results. See fun "killer charts" inside.

Tariffs: Rules keep changing, weekly. We think tariffs are bad for the US. Uncertainty, less efficiency = Bad for global growth. Copper tariff "head fake" = bad for valuations in space. Dollar: Peak weak? Or more to come? Market now pricing in rate cuts. China: Credit data OK. Consumption loans. Property bad. Energy transition: Continues apace, particularly outside US. Battery Storage = "New" marginal driver of metal demand. Solar = Lowest cost energy. Nuclear = fast regaining acceptance as solution to twin problems of decarbonization and energy security. China grid investment up, we see +8% this year.

Capex continues to ramp. Big Miner capex now more than 50% back toward previous peak. Companies seem to have mandate to grow again. Project execution is "mixed", e.g., Jansen overrun. QBII ramp continues to disappoint. GLEN (Glencore) applied for Argentina RIGI for projects, spotlight on copper optionality (see report: GLEN). Costs broadly (and unusually) seem to be under control as war- driven wave of inflation unwinds, mainly via energy.

Copper: Supply disappointing down: Seismic/flood incident at IVN/DRC, TECK QBII ramp slow, accident Chile. TCRCs still negative = Copper concentrate supply tight. Iron ore: RIO highlights marginal cost support, says market can (easily?) take new Simandou supply. Lithium: Rallying off lows on supply cuts in China; "anti- involution" in focus. Gold: Windfall cashflows in sector today from gold. Bulks free cash flow "subdued".
Many commodities on marginal cost = no more downgrades? Coal, iron ore, alumina.

BHP (Buy): Smoothing copper production at decade end. Jansen cost overrun. Projects. Rio Tinto (Buy): New CEO. Copper growth. Oyu Tolgoi ramp. Lithium price bottomed? Glencore (Buy): Coal off troughs. Copper: Tough H2 to deliver. Project syndication? Anglo American (Buy): Restructuring milestones in H2. Key commodities delivering. VALE (Buy): Volume (and base metals cost improvement) driving profit. TECK (Buy): Delivering copper growth but QB ramp- up issues = guidance headwinds. South32 (Buy): Copper and Aluminium key drivers. Nickel out. Pressure on Mozal. Fortescue (Underperform): Iron price impacts profit. Eyes on decarbonization capex. Freeport (Buy): "Goto" copper blue- chip. US champion. Leaching driving growth. Antofagasta (Buy): +30% low- risk volume growth, quality copper leverage. ArcelorMittal (Buy): Consolidating Calvert. Investor "hope" on EU policy.

As we often do, we select a few "killer charts" and explain why we think they are important. What makes a "killer chart"? It contains a simple, powerful and sometimes unexpected message. [Aside: Our annual "killer charts" note post our global Metals & Mining Conference (link: "Killer charts from our Global Conference") is often our best read note of the year]
Iron ore: The market is too bearish
Exhibit 6: Iron ore cost curve 2024E in 2018 vs. 2024 actual. The 2024 cost curve was steeper than previously forecast. This means a higher price is required for the market to balance.
Iron ore industry cost curve in 2024
BoFA GLOBAL RESEARCH

Why did we choose this chart? The market is (almost) universally bearish iron ore. Why? A new iron ore mine, Simandou, is coming online in Guinea and will add c. \(6\%\) to global supply. Investors are also bearish on the outlook for Chinese steel production. And yet the iron ore price still seems to hold the \(\) 90/\(t level. We hear from investors that our long - term iron ore price of\) \ \(92 / t\) (2025S) is "top of the Street" (to us, if anything, it feels conservative). RIO makes the following points: (1) costs have exceeded expectations; (2) producers globally face depletion; and (3) approximately \(40\%\) of production from the majors needs to be replaced over the next 10 years. Simandou: Expect to be absorbed with depletion of existing mines and healthy demand. High grade products actively sought after by customers.
Battery demand increased by \(38\%\) YoY in H1 2025 vs. H1 2024. A particular positive surprise was from BESS i.e. Battery Energy Storage Systems - stationary grid scale batteries.
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

Why did we choose this chart? The market has been very bearish on the lithium outlook with prices \(- 85 - 90\%\) from peak. Rio Tinto is bullish on the medium- term lithium outlook and is committing a lot of capital to the commodity. The upside surprise in demand from Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) could be a key underappreciated driver for demand into the medium term. With announced supply side closures in China, this could be the beginning of a bottom process for the lithium price cycle.
Exhibit 8: BHP share of EBITDA by commodityIn 2021, group EBITDA from iron ore was over \(70\%\) , copper contribution \(Source: Company

Why did we choose this chart? While we think that all large mining companies want more exposure to copper, more than anybody else, we see BHP taking active steps to increase copper share of EBITDA via both organic growth and inorganic M&A. BHP is not a small company – EV c. US\(154 bn. In our view, this makes this pivot all the more markable. We don't think this "project" is finished, either.
Exhibit 9: Escondida copper production (Mt)
Escondida copper production will decrease to c. 1 Mtpa for the years 2027-2031. But the previous decline to c. 750 ktpa has been removed now.
Optimised Escondida medium term production profile33
BoFA GLOBAL RESEARCH

**Why did we choose this chart?** In late 2024, BHP took c. 50 investors and analysts to visit its Latam copper operations including Escondida, the largest copper mine in the world. The message? The group needed to demolish its aging Los Colorados concentrator to be able to access a higher grade part of the ore body. This process would lead to a (large) dip in production to c. 750 ktpa. The group has now reconsidered its options and will run the Los Colorados concentrator for longer, which effectively removes this dip in production. We are slightly baffled that the company couldn't come to this conclusion before it hosted its site visit.
**Copper production weighted to H2**
**Exhibit 10: Glencore copper production weighting H1/H2 2025**

Glencore's copper production in 2025 will be v weighted to H2, with copper production anticipated to increase c. 50% HoH to 526 kt (mid-point). Most of this is driven by higher grades at key producing assets.
Copper (kt) - H1:H2 40:60 - FY 850-890kt

Why did we choose this chart? Glencore H1 copper production was down \(- 26\%\) Yoy - a negative surprise to the market. Why? (Expected) lower grades at key producing assets. Still, with this magnitude of decline in H1 production GLEN's copper production in 2025 will be very much weighted to H2, with copper production anticipated to increase c. \(50\%\) HoH to \(526\mathrm{kt}\) (mid- point). Most of this is being driven by higher grades at key producing assets. From discussions with investors, we think this makes the market nervous. We understand that Q3, while better than Q2, still won't be particularly strong. As such, the company is putting a lot of pressure on itself to deliver in Q4.
Exhibit 11: Glencore historic marketing profit (EBIT) US\(bn Glencore raised its guidance for profit from marketing from\)2.2- 3.2bn through the cycle to\)2.3- 3.5bn
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

Why did we choose this chart? Glencore's marketing business is (still) sometimes thought of as a bit of a "black box". We don't agree; we've previously written a primer explaining how the business makes money and is financed. See: Marketing division primer Mk V. Guidance for marketing profit has been \(2.2 - 3.2bn\) through the cycle for many years now despite the group earning above this level for the last several years. Finally, GLEN has raised the guide citing historical performance; growth in core metals and energy business, via entry into new markets and expansion of existing product lines, including LNG (liquefied natural gas), alumina, steelmaking coal, lithium etc; inflation progression to today's dollars; and [despite] the loss of c. \(0.2bn\) p.a. share of earnings from Viterra.
Exhibit 12: Anglo American reserves by asset Anglo American has \(30+\) years at all of its key copper assets with resources c. \(2.6x\) the existing reserve base
Source: Company data
Why did we choose this chart? Bottom line, Anglo has good copper assets in terms of resources in ground - \(30+\) years at key copper assets with resources c. \(2.6x\) the existing
reserve base. We think this endowment was a key driver of BHP's failed approach to Anglo in 2024.

Exhibit 13: Freeport = America's copper championFreeport operates fully integrated operations in the Southwest USA including upstream copper mines with SXEW facilities as well as downstream smelting and refining operations.
Source: Company data
BoFA GLOBAL RESEARCH

Why did we choose this chart? At a time when security of supply and national security loom large for the US administration, Freeport seems well placed with its large domestic US production base. While the latest "version" of copper tariffs didn't end up delivering the expected/hoped for benefit to the copper mining industry, we aren't convinced that this story is over yet. Higher COMEX premiums vs. LME copper means extra earnings for Freeport from its US assets. The group's copper production base is split roughly \(39\%\) Indonesia, \(34\%\) USA, \(27\%\) South America.

Exhibit 14: Teck copper growth potentialFrom 446 kt of copper production in 2024, updated 2025E guidance implies an increased of 25- 80 kt of copper with longer term production potential of up to 800 ktpa.
Source: Company data

Why did we choose this chart? As discussed above for Anglo American, TECK has an impressive endowment and interesting growth optionality. Near term, the company has disappointed the market with ongoing issues related to the ramp- up of the QBII mine, but longer term we think the value creation potential is clear. In our view, there are effectively two copper businesses "of scale" that could be biddable medium term: TECK and Anglo American. It isn't a coincidence that both of these businesses have (factually) already been bid for in the past (GLEN for TECK in 2023 and BHP for AAL in 2024).
Exhibit 15: Antofagasta has \(30\%\) volume growth ANTO delivering \(30\%\) volume growth through low- risk brownfields projects at existing mines, Los Pelambres and Centinela

Why did we choose this chart? At the risk of being overly simplistic: No other copper miner of scale has \(30\%\) volume growth through 2027- 28. And we think ANTO's low- risk brownfield projects where capital is largely sunk are (still) underappreciated by market.

Exhibit 16: ArcelorMittal EBITDA/t through cycle - Rebasing profitability higher EBITDA/t has been rebased structurally higher with this cycle low of c. \(\) 125/t$ materially higher than 2012- 2019 average EBITDA of US\\$89/t.

Why did we choose this chart? In spite of a very challenging market environment, MT EBITDA/t has been rebased structurally higher with this cycle low of c. \(\) 125/t$ materially higher than 2012- 2019 average EBITDA of US\\$89/t. How? We think a combination of
strategic investments and "high- grading" the portfolio. Result? A more resilient business through the cycle.
Exhibit 17: Expanded net debt progression US\(mn The group's expanded net debt (including provisions) now within the target range of US\) 10- 20 bn = Potential for increased capital return

Why did we choose this chart? VALE's expanded net debt (including provisions) now with the target range of US\(10- 20 bn = Potential for increased capital return. We think that investors may not consider that the cash outflows associated with Samarco and Brumadinho are now effectively provisioned for and included in this expanded net debt.
Link: Resilience in a "price down" year. Positive dividend surprise, originally published 19 August 2025, lead author J. Fairclough.

BHP reported FY25 financials broadly in line with consensus. Production previously released in July. EBITDA US\(26 bn, - 10\% YoY, + 1\% vs. consensus (Company supplied). Underlying EPS US\)2.00, - 26\% YoY, in line with consensus. FY DPS US\)1.10/sh, - 25\% YoY, + 9\% vs consensus ratio, payout ratio 55\%. Net debt US\(12.9 bn, + 41\% YoY, - 2\% vs consensus. Key takeaways: 1) Net debt target range revised up, now US\)10- 20bn (from US\)5- 15bn). 2) Jansen phase I capex + 26\% to \(7 - 7.4 bn. Jansen Stage 2 extended by 2 years. 3) WAOI medium term target production of >305 Mtpa. 4) Escondida (copper) to extend Los Colorados concentrator beyond FY29 = smooths production profile. Model: Minor changes to model. Shares trade on c. 0.8x NPV, through cycle c. 0.6- 1.1x P/NPV. Reiterate Buy, price objective A\)46, unchanged, still 1x updated NPV.

As a reminder, BHP plans to spend (roughly) US\(10.5- 14.4 bn to effectively "stand still" in its Chilean copper operations. Most of financial community is already bullish copper. However, for BHP, extreme bullishness comes at the end of this decade. BHP will now extend the operating life of the Los Colorados concentrator beyond 2029 to help smooth production profile over this period. This is in addition to low capital intensity initiatives across Laguna Seca concentrators. Initiatives will drive incremental c.400kt cumulatively over FY27 and FY31. Potential FID for new concentrator by CY27- 28. Elsewhere, BHP highlights new(ish) Vicuña JV with Lundin (Argentina) to be top- 10 copper producer.

Progress on Jansen disappointing to downside with capex for this 1st stage (of 4) to increase from \(5.7 bn to\) 7- 7.4 bn. BHP highlighting cost inflation, design development and scope changes and lower productivity outcomes (issues managing contractors). First production pushed back out to mid- 2027 (inline with original schedule). Stage 2 first production pushed out by 2 years, capex under review. Near term lower capex. Bottom line, between write- downs on initial spend on shaft and now overruns on stage 1, this has NOT been a positive project experience for BHP, in our view.
Link: Copper drives EBITDA beat. Lithium = c. \(\) 10\(bn business for"free"? originally published 31 July 2025, lead author J. Fairclough.

EBITDA beat, driven by copper. Net profit slight miss on higher tax \(=\) DPS slightly light. EBITDA \(\) 11.5\(bn, - 5\% \text{YoY}, + 2\% \text{vs}\) consensus. Net profit \(\) 4.8\(bn, - 16\% \text{YoY}, - 5\% \text{vs}\) consensus. DPS, \(\) 1.48/\(sh, - 16\% \text{YoY}, - 8\% \text{vs}\) consensus. No change to guide except copper C1 costs slightly down (by- products, strong production). In divisions: Iron ore inline, aluminium small beat, copper big beat. We see limited downside to iron ore from here and are bullish copper and aluminium calling them to\) \ \(12,000 / t\) & \(\) 3250/t\(respectively.

While investors tend to think of RIO as an iron ore "pure play", this isn't really the case anymore. The group's copper and aluminium assets were both material contributors to EBITDA in H1 (c. \(25\%\) and \(20\%\) respectively). Oyu Tolgoi (copper, Mongolia) in particular is becoming a major contributor as copper production from the new underground block cave mine ramps up. Revenue at Oyu Tolgoi increased c. \(90\%\) year- on- year, to \(\) 1.9\(bn with EBITDA increasing\) 145\% \(to\) \ \(1.2\) bn, more than \(10\%\) of group EBITDA. This will continue to increase as production ramps at the mine. We forecast EBITDA at \(>\) 4.5 bn/year by 2028. Overall, RIO highlights c. \(6\%\) copper equivalent growth across the company YoY (vs. H1 2024), no small feat for a company of its size.

For the first time, Rio reported sales & earnings from its lithium business. For now these are small: Sales \(\) 308\(mn, EBITDA\) \ \(42\) mn vs. group totals of c. \(\) 50\(bn &\) \ \(21\) bn. That said, with completion of the acquisition of Arcadium for c. \(\) 6\(bn and spend elsewhere, operating assets in this business are now >\) \ \(9\) bn. We believe that the market is effectively ignoring or discounting this business. At c. \(\) 10,000/t\(, down from a peak of\) \ \(90,000/t\) lithium prices do seem to be closer to a trough than a peak but we do see the market as being well (over) supplied for the next few years. RIO highlighting grid scale battery demand surprising up = another demand driver. Rio is hosting a site visit to its Argentina lithium assets later this year including its \(\) 2.5\(bn Rincon project.
Link: Eyes on cost cuts. No more coal downgrades?, originally published 7 August 2025, lead author J. Fairclough.

EBITDA US \(5.4 bn, - 14\%\) YoY, inline with our estimate and company supplied consensus. Marketing EBIT previously guided US \(1.36 bn, inline. Net debt US\) 14.5 bn, \(+30\%\) from year- end 2024, higher than consensus at US \(12.9 bn. GLEN sees unwind of non- RMI working capital into H2 and stronger production (40/60 split) driving deleveraging.\) 1 bn cost savings, previously announced. Marketing through cycle EBIT guide raised (with production result) to US \(2.3 - 3.5 bn. Company updated indicative spot earnings: EBITDA US\) 14.2 bn, spot FCF \(4 bn. Spot EBITDA aligns with our estimated mark- to- market of\) 14.1 bn. We are bullish on copper, GLEN \(=\) leverage to view.

The group provided details on its newly announced cost savings programme. \(\) 1\(bn/year, 76\%\) operations, \(18\%\) department overhead, \(6\%\) corporate. What do we think? This figure, \(\) 1\(bn/year, is very material (c. 8%) relative to 2025E EBITDA of c.\) 13 bn/year. It is very material relative to 2026E net income of US\) 3 bn/year. That said, most of the time (and this is not GLEN specific) we do take a "show me" approach on cost cutting i.e. we don't model them explicitly. In our experience, often, even as cuts are "delivered", we don't actually see earnings going up, rather the cuts end up being consumed in partially offsetting inflation. Let's see. We hope to be positively surprised!

Unlike large- cap peers, for GLEN, coals (both thermal & coking) are still very important earnings drivers. Consensus (Bloomberg) 2025E EBITDA estimate has "ground down" from an estimate of c. \(\) 20\(bn in 2022 to current consensus estimate of c.\) 12.8 bn with much of this negative mark being driven by coal price assumption downgrades. Recently prices for both thermal coal and coking coal troughed well into their respective cost curves ( \(
Link: H1 fine. Key divisions (copper, iron ore) delivering, originally published 1 August 2025, lead author J. Fairclough.

A slightly complicated print given several businesses now classified as discontinued. Headline EBITDA, \(\) 2.96\(bn, - 20\%\) YoY, \(+3\%\) vs adjusted, continuing operations Visible Alpha consensus, \(+12\%\) vs our estimate. Dividend US \(\) 0.07\(/sh, - 42\%\) YoY, light vs. Street at \(\) 0.12\(because calculated based on an"all" operations EPS figure). Net debt US\) \ \(10.8\) bn vs. consensus \(\) 11.6\(bn. Key divisions, copper, iron ore ahead. DeBeers light. Restructuring proceeding on many fronts. We like the destination for this"journey". Buy price objective GBp2600

PGMs: Now (mostly) gone, Anglo demerged c. \(51\%\) of its interest in Valterra June \(1^{\mathrm{st}}\) however, it still holds a c. \(19.9\%\) stake. Anglo intends to retain this shareholding for at least 90 days following demerger with this shareholding position to be managed responsibly over time to affect a full separation. Coal sale: There has been market concern (See our note: Coal Angst) about this transaction given an ignition event at the Moranbah mine, which led to (safe) evacuation of personnel & shutdown. Anglo is now progressing toward a mine restart at Moranbah and continues to believe that the event doesn't constitute a material adverse change (MAC) under the agreement with BTU. The agreed sale was previously targeted for completion by Q3 2025. Nickel: Sale agreed. DeBeers/Diamonds: Sales process & IPO/spin "dual track" in progress. Market tough.

Post BHP's approach to Anglo American last year, Anglo is pursuing a strategy of simplification. At the end of the journey, AAL should be a focussed copper & high- quality iron ore producer (Aside - with a revenue mix very similar to BHP). "NewCo" should have higher margins, higher returns and stronger FCF generation. We think that Anglo's high quality copper business is one of very few of size that could potentially be acquired. See our recent note: Copper Equity Handbook. The iron ore business, while lacking the scale of majors such as BHP, RIO & VALE, does produce high quality, premium products that will be in demand as the global steel industry decarbonizes.
Link: A strong showing in 2Q25 results showcasing bottom-up improvements, originally published 31 July 2025, lead author C. Ribeiro.

Vale reported 2Q25 results and Proforma EBITDA of \(\) 3,424\(mn (+6.6\% q / q; - 14.3\% y / y)\) which was \(8\%\) above our estimate and \(3.4\%\) above Bloomberg consensus ( \(7\%\) above consensus numbers gathered by Vale from sell- side analysts). The beat to our numbers was mainly a reflection of higher shipments (iron ore \(1\%\) above, copper and nickel \(8\%\) above BofAe) and better realized pricing for iron ore ( \(1\%\) above BofAe) and nickel ( \(4\%\) above BofAe) which offset slightly higher C1 iron ore cash costs ( \(1\%\) above BofAe) and lower realized copper prices ( \(6\%\) below BofAe). On a y/y basis Vale's EBITDA declined mainly due to lower realized iron ore prices (- \(13\%\) y/y) and nickel prices (- \(15\%\) y/y) yet partially compensated by higher copper and nickel shipments (+ \(17\%\) y/y and + \(21\%\) y/y) and lower C1 cash costs for iron ore (- \(7\%\) y/y). We calculate that FCFE (OCF - capex) came in at - \(\) 700\(mn while Net Debt/EBITDA was 0.9x (up 0.1x q / q) and expanded net debt was down to\) \ \(17.4bn\) from \(\) 18.2bn\(still within target leverage range of\) \ \(10\) - \(20bn). Vale also announced \(\) 1.448bn\(in interest on capital as per policy to be paid in September 2025 implying a yield of\) 3.3\% \(. We keep our Buy rating on Vale as valuation looks attractive at\) 4.1x EV/EBITDA 2026 and recognize bottom- up operational improvements.

Total iron ore production of \(83.6Mt\) rose \(3.7\% y / y\) , as higher volumes from the Northern and Southeast systems more than offset lower production from the South system (see our report). Iron ore sales (including pellets and ROM) of \(77.3Mt\) were \(1\%\) above our model and \(1.8\%\) below consensus. Ferrous EBITDA of \(\) 2,977\(mn was 6.9\%\) above our forecast as both fines and pellets results were ahead of us. C1 was at US\) \ \(26.3 / t\) , up \(6.6\%\) q/q and slightly above our forecast. For iron ore pellets, costs were below our estimates, driving EBITDA of US \(\) 477mn\(, 5\%\) above our forecast.

As we wrote in our production review, sales were at \(89Kt\) for copper (up \(- 6.6\%\) y/y) and \(41.4Kt\) for nickel, up \(6.4\%\) y/y. Copper sales were \(7.5\%\) above our forecast while nickel sales were \(8.4\%\) above BofAe. All in all, base metals revenue came in at \(\) 1.8bn\(, up - 6\%\) q/q and \(14\%\) y/y, \(5.9\%\) above our estimate, given the higher volumes and higher nickel prices vs our model. The higher base metals revenues drove base metals EBITDA of \(\) 721mn\(way above our forecast of\) \ \(499mn\) , up \(30\%\) q/q, and \(77\%\) y/y. The increase is explained by better operational results, higher fixed cost dilution and higher by- product revenues in the copper business, and higher feed availability in Voisey's Bay at lower cost, lower third- party costs, and inventory impairment reversal in the nickel business. Regarding costs, the all in costs for copper and nickel were \(\) 1,450/t\(and\) \ \(12,396/t\) , respectively. Down \(60\%\) y/y for copper, driven by higher by- product revenues and lower TC/RCs and other discounts, and down \(30\%\) y/y for nickel due to lower unit costs and higher copper sales
Link: Mixed Q2'25 earnings; QB2 2025 copper production guidance cut; HVC sanctioned, originally published 24 July 2025, lead author L. Winder.

Teck Resources (TECK) reported mixed Q2'25 earnings vs. consensus and BofAe, with EBITDA light and EPS beat. The 2025 copper production guidance range for the Quebrada Blanca 2 (QB2) copper growth project was reduced, and consolidated unit cost and capex guidance raised as a result. We think the cut should not be a material surprise to the market after Chilean government copper production statistics for April and May 2025 showed QB2 tracking well below the run- rate. While the guidance cut removes an overhang, in our view, and 2026- 28 QB2 guidance was held, we think investors will likely seek assurances for longer- term guidance on today's call. Capital return in Q2'25 remained robust, despite a material free cash outflow. As expected, TECK sanctioned the Highland Valley Copper (HVC) C\\$2.1- C\\$2.4 (up from C\\$1.8- C\\$2.0 prior) billion extension project. We reiterate our Buy rating given TECK's leading copper production growth outlook and robust capital return profile.

In Q2'25, TECK repurchased and cancelled C\\$494 million (m), or 9.75m units of its Class B shares (vs. C\\$389 (6.4m units) in Q1'25 and C\\$486m (7.5m units) in Q4'24), and paid C\\$61m (C\\$0.125 per share) via its quarterly dividend (in- line to Q1'25 and Q4'24). Through the end of H1'25, TECK has repurchased and cancelled C\\$883m of its outstanding Class B shares this year, bringing the total to C\\$2.2 billion (bn) since launch of the current C\\$3.25bn authorization (leaving C\\$1.0bn remaining). As of 30- Jun- 25, net debt was C\\$211m, vs. net cash of C\\$764bn as at 31- Mar- 25, and below BofAe at net cash of C\\$366bn, as a working capital build drove free cash flow to negative C\\$315m vs. BofAe at C\\$52m, Bloomberg (BBG) at C\\$263m, Visible Alpha (VA) at C\\$117m.

TECK updated its 2025 guidance ranges for copper/moly production, copper unit costs and capex. 2025 QB2 copper production range was lowered to 210- 230 thousand tonnes (kt) from 230- 270kt, and moly production range was cut to 1.7- 2.5kt from 3.0- 4.5kt. Given lower production and higher cost related to alternative shipping arrangements (following previously reported outage at the QB2 shiploader), 2025 consolidated copper unit cost guidance was increased to \(\) 2.25-\ \(2.45 per pound (/lb) from\) \ \(1.80 -\) 2.15/lb. With increased spending required for development of the tailings management facility (TMF) sustaining capex was increased by C\\$340m to C\\$940- 1,010m. Following the HVC project sanctioning, 2025 copper growth capex was raised C\\$300- 340m to \(\) 1,040- \(1,170m, and 2028 copper production guidance for HVC was increased 20kt to 90- 110kt.\)

Q2'25 adjusted EBITDA of C\\$227m was 6% below BofAe (due to higher copper unit costs), and 1% below BBG above VA consensus. Q2'25 copper volumes were 109kt vs. BofAe, BBG, and VA at 112kt, 119kt, and 117kt. Adjusted EPS of C\\$0.38 was well above BofAe at C\\$0.21 and BBG/VA at C\\$0.25/C\\$0.23 due to much lower taxes.

We maintain our Buy rating on FCX on the back of the strong earnings and BofA's bullish longer- term copper price outlook (FCX's primary product).

2025 sales guide cut but longer- term sales outlook intactFCX reduced its 2025 sales guidance to 3.95 billion pounds (Bib) of copper, 1.3 million ounces (Moz) of gold, and 82Mb of molybdenum (moly) from prior 2025 guidance of 4.0 Blb of copper, 1.6Moz of gold and 88 Mb of moly. FCX cited two reasons for the sales reduction, both associated with its Grasberg operation in Indonesia: 1) revised ore- grade modeling (that impacts 2025 but with little impact to the 5- year plan), and 2) inventory and sales adjustments related an "advanced" smelter start- up schedule (a positive in our view). FCX's 2025 unit net cash cost guidance was increased to \(\) 1.55\(per pound (/lb) from\) \ \(1.50\) /lb (and original guidance for \(\) 1.60/\(lb), as the benefit from a higher gold price assumption (\) \ \(3,300\) per ounce (/oz) vs. \(\) 3,000/\(oz prior) was more than offset by the reduction in 2025 gold sales. The unit cost guide excludes any potential impact from proposed U.S. tariffs. FCX expects 5% higher cost of goods in the U.S. due to supplier pass- through of tariffs, but is evaluating alternative sources for these supplies. 2025 capex guidance (ex - Indonesia downstream) was trimmed marginally to\) \ \(4.3\) billion (bn) from \(\) 4.4bn\(. For Q3'25, FCX is guiding to copper, gold, and moly sales of 990 Mlb, 350koz, and 18Mlb, vs. prior guide of 1,095Mlb, 475Moz and 23Mlb, respectively.

Q2 EBITDA beat on higher volume/pricing and lower costsFCX reported Q2'25 adjusted EPS of \(\) 0.54\(above BofAe / Bloomberg (BBG) / Visible Alpha (VA) consensus at\) \ \(0.37 /\) \ \(0.45 /\) \ \(0.46\) . Adjusted EBITDA of \(\) 3,191\(m beat BofAe / BBG / VA at\) \ \(2,817m /\) \ \(3,018m /\) \ \(2,975m\) . Copper and gold sales of 1,016Mlb and 522koz, were 1% and 4% above BofAe. C1 net cash costs of \(\) 1.13/\(lb, were lower than BofAe at\) \ \(1.20 /\) lb and better than the mid- April guide of \(\) 1.50/\(lb. The realized copper price (\) \ \(4.54 / lb\) ) was above our \(\) 4.48/\(lb estimate. Gold sales were 65% above production on the timing of shipments partly offset by lower grades. At the end of Q2'25, FCX held consolidated net debt (ND) of\) \ \(4.8bn\) (total debt of \(\) 9.3bn\(, cash/equivalents of\) \ \(4.5bn\) ), flat QoQ. ND to adjusted EBITDA was \(0.5x\) (vs. \(0.5x\) prior). We calculate Q2'25 free cash flow of \(\) 934m\(above BofAe\) \ \(686m\) . FCX repurchased \(\) 52m\(of shares in Q2'25 and\) \ \(107m\) in H'25.

Link: Death knell for Mozal? No power contract. No aluminium, originally published 14 August 2025, lead author J. Fairclough.

South32 announced that, as a result of unsuccessful discussions with its power suppliers in Mozambique / South Africa, it will begin the process of decapitalizing Mozal, its Mozambique aluminium smelter, with a view to placing the asset on care and maintenance from March 2026 when the current power contract runs out. Investments in pot- relining, typically done on a rolling basis, will cease due to the multi- month payback period associated with them. S32 will take a \(\) 372\(mn impairment against the asset. While the news is disappointing we still see deep value in shares.

This situation is really a shame, in our view. Mozal is a fairly well- run smelter and a major industrial asset in Mozambique, contributing c. \(3\%\) of GDP. Mozambique itself is naturally "long" hydro- electricity which supplies over \(90\%\) of local power. So what is the problem? We understand the issues relate to negotiations on transfer pricing and involves South32, Government of Mozambique, Hidroeléctrica de Cahora Bassa (HCB, a local utility) and Eskom (South African state- owned utility). The power used by Mozal is effectively generated in Mozambique but is transported to Mozal via South African grid. We understand negotiations have been ongoing for several years with little progress. S32 takes its duty to shareholders seriously and is unwilling to sign an unfair contract.

Aluminium smelting is one of the most energy intensive industrial process using c. 15- 16 MWh of power per tonne of metal smelted. Historically, aluminium has been produced in places that are naturally long cheap (ideally) hydro power; think Canada, Norway, Siberia. With an extensive hydro endowment, Mozambique should be well placed. More recent large investments in aluminium smelting were made in China powered by coal- fired generation. This put a high cost, high- carbon "shoulder" of supply into the cost curve. That said, we note that China is now investing aggressively into lower carbon energy sources such as hydro, wind, solar and nuclear, so the rules could change again.
Link: Down YoY on iron ore. Eyes on decarbonization capex, originally published 26 August 2025, lead author J. Fairclough.

2025 EBITDA, \(7.9bn\) , \(- 26\%\) YoY, \(+2\%\) vs.consensus, \(+5\%\) vs BofAe. Underlying EPS \(1.10 / sh\) \(- 41\%\) YoY, \(- 3\%\) vs consensus, \(+2\%\) vs BofAe. DPS A\(1.10 / sh, 65\%\) payout ratio, \(- 44\%\) YoY, inline with consensus. Key driver of YoY decline in earnings & dividend? Lower iron ore price: Platts \(58\%\) iron ore \(- 17\%\) YoY to c. \(87 / t\) . FMG's stated realization \(85 / t, 84\%\) of the benchmark \(62\%\) price. We update our model for results. 2026E EBITDA broadly flat at c. US\(6.4 bn. Reiterate Underperform, price objective A\) 17 still based on 0.8x P/NPV target. Key issues: Iron ore view. Capital allocation.

We believe the Street could be overly bearish iron ore. Our own forecasts are for \(90 / t\) into CY2026, \(80 / t\) into 2027. That said, discussions with clients indicate our long- term iron ore price ( \(92 / t\) in 2025\) is "top of the street". As such, in our view, there is already a lot of negativity on both iron ore outlook and iron ore equities. Large- cap iron ore producers trade at discounts to NPV/DCF (P/NPV BHP 0.9x, RIO LN 0.7x, RIO AU, 0.8x, VALE 0.8x, FMG 0.9x). At recent H1 2025 results, Rio Tinto suggested that iron ore cost curve has steepened, with marginal cost surprising UP vs. its own expectations indicating cost support at c. \(90 / t\). Depletion also an issue for iron ore. Negativity around incremental tonnes from the Simandou project in Guinea could also be overdone.

Fortescue is, at its core, a highly cash generative business through the cycle. In our view, THE key issue is capital allocation. We are intrigued by FMG's efforts to decarbonize large- scale mobile mining equipment at its own iron ore operations. Time will tell if this is a success. If this ultimately works, we think this is a good thing for the industry (and indeed, the world). That said, as with the roll- out of autonomous mining, we understand how other companies may choose to be "fast followers" rather than "trailblazers". Separately, FMG's wider foray into non- mining green investments seems to be winding down (slowly). For us a key tension here has always been using high- cost mining capital to fund low- cost of capital (and return) green investments.
Link: H1 in line. DPS small positive surprise. Buy for "blue chip" copper exposure, originally published 14 August 2025, lead author J. Fairclough.

Antofagasta 1H25: Inline. EBITDA US\(2.2 bn, +60\%\) YoY, - 1% vs our estimate +2% vs company consensus. EPS \(0.47 / sh, +5\%\) vs our estimate and consensus interim dividend US\(0.166, +5\%\) vs us / consensus. Net debt \(2.3 bn, - 2.5\%\) (i.e. lower) than consensus. Guide: Maintained, 2025 production of 660- 700kt, net cash costs \(1.45 - 1.65 / lb\). Maintain BUY. We are bullish copper calling it to \(12,000 / t\) in 2027. Antofagasta shares give leverage to this positive view.

According to ANTO: Post period- end, additional maintenance has taken place at Los Pelambres on tailings pipeline, which connects the processing plant to the tailings facility. The impact of this is expected to be a reduction in copper production of between 5- 10 kt tonnes. Conversely, production at Centinela quite strong so overall guidance unchanged. Site visit: Later this year (November) ANTO will host investors & analysts at site. Most of the time, we think that companies host visits when they have a GOOD story to tell. In the case of ANTO, the story is competent delivery on its brownfield growth projects. Material volume growth = quite rare among copper majors.

When thinking about mining investing we consider first "Top down" = Decision to own (Macro/China + Energy transition + India + Al). Then "Bottom up" i.e. for stock picking, we use a simple framework: 1) Price 2) Volume 3) Self- help. For Antofagasta (ANTO), we consider: 1) Price: Our commodity team is bullish copper, calling it to \(12,000 / t\). ANTO has a correlation of 0.9 with copper price. 2) Volume: We model c. 30% volume growth through 2027E (vs. 2024). This is stand- out volume growth amongst larger cap copper pure- plays. 3) Self- help: ANTO had a few difficult years with water shortages hurting its largest mine, Los Pelambres. ANTO has commissioned a desalination plant to mitigate the issue going forward. So, to sum up; Price: Tick. Volume: Tick. Self- help: Tick.
Link: 2Q25 Results: Earnings in- line, eyes on EU policy response, originally published 31 July 2025, lead author R. van der Walt.

ArcelorMittal (MT) reported 1H25 EBITDA \(+1\%\) v consensus. Europe stronger and North America weaker than expected. Outlook: Global ex- China demand outlook revised down but unsurprising given YTD tariff developments. MT trades at a \(- 20\%\) EV/EBITDA discount to European and US peers (historic average \(- 34 - 17\%\) ). We further rerating potential MT (our PO implies \(- 14\%\) spread) as the company 1) continues its disciplined capital investment (grow through cycle + conservative decarbonisation), and 2) Regional diversification provides a buffer against tariff uncertainty and geopolitical risks relative to peers.

Company outlook for apparent steel consumption revised down relative to previous view at FY results in Feb- 25 (MT only updates outlook half- yearly). In our view, this is unsurprising given the trade tensions that have since unfolded. Biggest change is for US flat product demand (now see \(- 2\%\) to flat vs \(+1 - 3\%\) prior). MT estimates German Infrastructure Fund adding \(+1.5 - 2\%\) to annual steel demand in Europe. Similar to industry peers, MT believes an effective CBAM (cross border adjustment mechanism)/ safeguard replacement could be the catalyst needed for Europe to move up from cyclical lows. As such, next 12 months could be catalyst rich. An effective CBAM needs (at a minimum) to address 1) circumvention, 2) export rebates and 3) steel derivate product inclusion (e.g. auto, machinery).

We see broadly flat EBITDA from 1H25 to 2H25 before picking up into FY26 (mainly strategic projects ramping up). 1- 2H Incremental earnings from new capacity adds would be c. US500bn including Calvert acquisition adding c. \(\) 120\(m and final Liberia ramp - up adding\) \ \(50m\) . New capacity adds will be offset by EU and US seasonality (we estimate c. - US\) 60m headwind). EU and US spreads could offset each other (EU down, US up HoH) based on prices in recent months. Tariffs add a further c. \(\) 180m\(headwind.

Our price objective of GBp2600/USS17 ADR, 1.0x our multiple- and discounted cash flow (DCF)- derived sum of the parts (SOTP). For DCF inputs, we use a weighted- average cost of capital (WACC) of \(9\%\) , terminal growth of \(2\%\) if appropriate. We consider the potential for new political leadership in South Africa to arrest the derating of the South African mining sector versus global peers. We assume that Anglo's shares in listed subsidiaries Kumba and Anglo Platinum are valued based on market prices. We value fertilizer based on a risked NPV.

Risks to our price objective are a sustained slowdown in global economic growth (in particular China, the key driver of commodity consumption), a strengthening of the Rand exchange rate, an escalation of other cost pressures such as labour and energy prices, poor operational performance leading to missed production targets. An improving macro outlook leading to higher commodity prices and implementation of the announced asset optimisation target could provide upside risks to our EPS and valuation.

Our price objective of GBp2400 is based on 8x our average 2026E/27E attributable EBITDA. During periods of low metal prices we think that base metal stocks trade on higher earnings multiples. They can also trade on higher multiples during periods of rising metal prices. Our target multiple is similar to where other high quality copper producers are currently trading. We believe this is justified because Antofagasta is a high quality copper company whose shares exhibit high correlation to the copper price.
Downside/upside risks: Global macro, commodity demand, commodity prices, strikes, resource nationalism, concentration in a single country.

Our price objective of EUR 31 (US\(35.50/ADR) is based on a sum- of- the- parts (SOTP) valuation approach. We apply relevant regional EV/EBITDA multiples to major divisions to derive a value per segment. We sum these up, subtract a 20% "HoldCo" discount and subtract group net debt to arrive at a group equity value.

Upside risks to our price objective are faster- than- expected growth in major steel- consuming sectors, a "restocking" cycle in major steel end markets, a major reconstruction effort in Ukraine driving steel demand and prices, lower steel exports from China leading to higher global steel prices.

Downside risks to our price objective are economic recession in the EU and US impacting demand for steel, decline in construction, machinery and automotive spending in MT's key markets (Europe, North America, Brazil) resulting in lower demand, high exports from China (and other regions) pressuring global prices, M&A that strains the balance sheet, lower iron ore pressuring prices and earnings in the Seaborne Iron Ore division.

Our price objective of A\(46/share (US\)57/share) represents c. 1.0x our DCF- derived NPV. Our DCF is based on BofA commodity price forecasts and assumes a 9% discount rate. Diversified miners traded in a range of 0.7- 1.4x NPV over the last five years with lower multiples paid during periods of economic slowdown and higher multiples paid during periods of rising commodity prices and earnings.
Downside (upside) risks to our price objective are: Global economic slowdown (growth),
volatility in commodity prices, operational risks associated with mining, project execution risk, currency pressures and mining cost inflation (deflation).

Our \(\) 17.00\(/sh price objective is set based on c. 0.8x P/NPV target. Key components are a DCF valuation, which applies a WACC of 9.4% to the estimated life of mine cash flows. Through the cycle, bulk commodity miners trade at 0.6 - 1.4x NPV with higher multiples being paid during periods of rising commodity prices.

Downside risks: 1) FMG's key commodity, iron ore, is skewed to the demand profile of the major global buyer, China and relative growth of industry suppliers. With slowing Chinese growth, iron ore prices could fall, which could negatively impact FMG also additional growth from industry players above forecasts could lead to lower iron ore prices and also FMG, 2) FMG continues to pay down debt and a decrease in iron ore prices may pressure repayments, however this risk is lower than prior years.

Upside risks: 1) Favorable moves in iron ore above our LT estimates and also a lower the AS/USS currency would lower FMG's cost position and 2) a slowing of mining growth in Western Australia has seen input prices (labour being key) moderate - - these could fall further and lower costs further than our estimates.

Our \(\) 49.0\(- per - share price objective blends 8.0x 2025E, 7.5x 2026E EV/EBITDA and 1.0x our net asset value (NAV). The 8.0x EV/EBITDA target multiple is largely in - line with the historical average for copper producers covered by BofA. We think this is appropriate given stable production profile, low unit costs and a improving balance sheet. Our P/NAV multiple of 1.0x is in line with most of the copper producers covered by BofA but is arguably conservative given several potentially value enhancing growth options that we do not currently model. These include a new mill at El Abra, a mill expansion at Bagdad, and low - grade leaching.

Downside risks to our price objective are 1) global economic weakness, 2) Operating disruptions, 3) execution risk at its cost- cutting or expansion programs, 4) stricter or unfavorable regulatory or environmental regulations, particularly at its Indonesian operations, 5) other factors pressuring prices of the commodities it produces, and 6) unfavorable currency moves.
Upside risks are 1) better- than- expected copper and gold prices, 2) a more accommodating operating environment in Indonesia, and 3) further cost- cutting progress.

Our price objective of GBp370 (ADR \(\) 10.00)\(is c.1.0x our discounted cash flow (DCF) - and multiple - derived sum of the parts (SOTP). Through the cycle large - cap diversified miners have traded between 0.7x and 1.3x net present value (NPV, weighted - average cost of capital: c.10%, terminal growth rate: 2%) with higher multiples being paid during periods of rising commodity prices. Shares of more financially and operationally leveraged vehicles, such as Glencore, tend to trade at premiums to NPV during periods of positive outlook for miners and lower multiples during periods of challenging economic outlook.

Upside/downside risks to our price objective are commodity prices being stronger/weaker than our forecasts, trading profits being better/worse than our estimates, better/worse- than- modelled cost savings at industrial assets, positive/negative operational surprises at the group's industrial assets, a rise/decline in the market value of the group's listed assets.

Rio Tinto Ltd (RTNTF)Our \(150 / share price objective is based on 1.00x net present value (NPV). Our NPV uses 9% WACC and 2% terminal growth rate. Rio Tinto Ltd. tends to trade at a premium to its London listing (Rio Tinto Plc.) due to the availability of franking credits to Australian investors - this premium has averaged 9% over the last 12 years.

South32 Ltd (SHTLF)Our A \(3.50 / sh\) price objective is set broadly in line with 1.0x our DCF- derived NPV, calculated using BofA commodity prices and a 10% WACC and 0% terminal growth rate.

We set our price objective (PO) for TECK at \(41 per share (C\) 56 per share). This is based on 7.0x 2025E EBITDA, 6.5x 2026E EV/EBITDA and 1.20x NAV for the base metals business. The 8.0 EV/EBITDA target multiple is at the mid of the range of 4.0- 10.0x used to value the copper producers. Given TECK's copper volume growth, it's suite of additional organic copper production growth options, and relatively attractive jurisdictional exposure, the market could assign a higher multiple to the base metal business. We assume USDCAD = 1.37.

Downside risks to our price objective are: 1) global economic weakness, specifically in China and India, 2) excess supply given China's position and recent elevated prices, 3) unplanned Teck operating disruptions, 4) stricter regulatory or environmental measures, 5) other factors pressuring prices of the commodities it produces.

Upside risks to our price objective are: the potential to monetize its copper projects, especially if copper prices exceed our expectations, and potentially greater success in its cost- savings/efficiency initiatives.

Vale (VALE / VALEF)Our US \(11 (R\) 60/ share) PO is based on a 50/50 blended valuation approach. On multiples, we use a 4.5x 2025E EV/EBITDA (close to the past 5 years average, as our price forecast is now on a more normalized level, although above our long- term price,
which is why we use a multiple below the "fair" 5.0x) and our DCF using a WACC of \(11.9\%\) and terminal growth rate of \(2.5\%\)

Downside risks to our price objective: 1) weaker than expected iron ore prices, 2) a global economic slowdown, negatively impacting metals prices, 3) appreciation of the Brazilian Real and the Canadian Dollar (80% of Vale's costs are denominated in those currencies), without an offsetting increase in metal prices, 4) slowdown in infrastructure spending or global steel production, mainly in China, 5) higher freight rates, reducing Vale's competitiveness in China, 6) higher government intervention, and 7) more fallout from its Brumadinho tailings dam tragedy.

Upside risks: 1) Stronger than expected iron ore prices, 2) stronger than expected global economic growth, 3) acceleration of infrastructure spending or global steel production, mainly in China, and 4) change in China's policy on steel production cuts.

FUNDAMENTAL EQUITY OPINION KEY: Opinions include a Volatility Risk Rating, an Investment Rating and an Income Rating. VOLATILITY RISK RATINGS, indicators of potential price fluctuation, are: A - Low, B - Medium and C - High. INVESTMENT RATINGS reflect the analyst's assessment of both a stock's absolute total return potential as well as its attractiveness for investment relative to other stocks within its Coverage Cluster (defined below). Our investment ratings are: 1 - Buy stocks are expected to have a total return of at least \(10\%\) and are the most attractive stocks in the coverage cluster; 2 - Neutral stocks are expected to remain flat or increase in value and are less attractive than Buy rated stocks and 3 - Underperform stocks are the least attractive stocks in a coverage cluster. An investment rating of 6 (No Rating) indicates that a stock is no longer trading on the basis of fundamentals. Analysts assign investment ratings considering, among other things, the 0- 12 month total return expectation for a stock and the firm's guidelines for ratings dispersions (shown in the table below). The current price objective for a stock should be referenced to better understand the total return expectation at any given time. The price objective reflects the analyst's view of the potential price appreciation (depreciation).
Investment ratingTotal return expectation (within 12-month period of date of initial rating)Ratings dispersion guidelines for coverage clusterR2Buy≥ 10%≤ 70%Neutral≥ 0%≤ 30%UnderperformN/A≥ 20%
R2Ratings disions may vary from time to time where BofA Global Research believes it better reflects the investment prospects of stocks in a Coverage Cluster.

INCOME RATINGS, indicators of potential cash dividends, are: 7 - same/higher (dividend considered to be secure), 8 - same/lower (dividend not considered to be secure) and 9 - pays no cash dividend.
